articles.headline: Scientists Add Letters to DNA’s Alphabet, Raising Hope and Fear
articles.snippet: There is still a long way to go before there will be any practical antibiotics, vaccines or other products from the research.
articles.abstract: There is still a long way to go before there will be any practical antibiotics, vaccines or other products from the research.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scientists reported Wednesday that they had taken a significant step toward altering the fundamental alphabet of life — creating an organism with an expanded artificial genetic code in its DNA.

articles.headline: Forget 1960, the Golden Age Is Now
articles.snippet: Much of the high-end market today is in business-class travel, where airlines have spent huge sums to compete.
articles.abstract: Much of the high-end market today is in business-class travel, where airlines have spent huge sums to compete.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you fly a lot, you have heard the nostalgia about a long-gone Golden Age of air travel. During this fabled time, which is said to have occurred as commercial aviation expanded through the 1950s into the jet age of the 1960s, passengers dressed up to fly on airplanes where glamorous stewardesses wearing white gloves served beef bourguignon on fine china.

articles.headline: Piling On the Luxury
articles.snippet: To compete for high-value business travelers, airlines are engaged in an amenities arms race, investing in better seats, private terminals and hosts of other perks for their premium passengers.
articles.abstract: To compete for high-value business travelers, airlines are engaged in an amenities arms race, investing in better seats, private terminals and hosts of other perks for their premium passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most travelers, flying in style may be a thing of the past, but airlines are determined to bring back some glamour to air travel, at least for those sitting in the front of the plane.

articles.headline: U.S. Issues Safety Alert for Oil Trains
articles.snippet: After a series of accidents, the Department of Transportation has ordered railroads carrying large shipments of crude oil to notify state emergency workers.
articles.abstract: After a series of accidents, the Department of Transportation has ordered railroads carrying large shipments of crude oil to notify state emergency workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Calling the movement of crude oil by rail an “imminent hazard” to the public, the federal Department of Transportation said on Wednesday that railroads would be required to notify local emergency responders whenever oil shipments traveled through their states.

articles.headline: Alibaba Bets on a Growing Chinese Economy and New Consumers
articles.snippet: Alibaba wants to insert itself at the center of an already expanding market being forged by powerful economic and cultural forces.
articles.abstract: Alibaba wants to insert itself at the center of an already expanding market being forged by powerful economic and cultural forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: When American tech upstarts float their companies on the stock market, they often sell investors on a familiar dream — “disrupting” an existing industry. It doesn’t matter if the industry is advertising, software, commerce or some other sector. The start-up will usually claim that its business is a great technological leap forward that will greatly lower costs and improve service for customers and leave rivals unable to respond. Therefore, buy some stock.

articles.headline: Growing Pains for a Goldman Sachs Fund
articles.snippet: The bank, which surprised some on Wall Street when it created a new version of its Petershill investment fund, has had a hard time attracting investors.
articles.abstract: The bank, which surprised some on Wall Street when it created a new version of its Petershill investment fund, has had a hard time attracting investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Goldman Sachs’s most notable investment vehicles, Petershill, has been less than extraordinary, effectively saved by one good bet among a number of duds, and the bank even came close to selling it to Credit Suisse in 2012. So when Goldman started a second version of Petershill, which buys stakes in big-name hedge funds, it came as something of a surprise to people in the industry.

articles.headline: Some Investors Bet on Return to Reverse Mortgages
articles.snippet: A reverse mortgage start-up based in New Jersey has raised about $230 million in a private offering, which sets the stage for a potential initial public offering.
articles.abstract: A reverse mortgage start-up based in New Jersey has raised about $230 million in a private offering, which sets the stage for a potential initial public offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some private investors are betting that reverse mortgages, an investment product aimed at older people in need of cash, will make a resurgence as more homeowners reach retirement age in the coming years.

articles.headline: Miami Finds Itself Ankle-Deep in Climate Change Debate
articles.snippet: A new study has added to a roiling debate by naming the Miami area as among the most vulnerable to severe damage from rising sea levels.
articles.abstract: A new study has added to a roiling debate by naming the Miami area as among the most vulnerable to severe damage from rising sea levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — The sunny-day flooding was happening again. During high tide one recent afternoon, Eliseo Toussaint looked out the window of his Alton Road laundromat and watched bottle-green saltwater seep from the gutters, fill the street and block the entrance to his front door.

articles.headline: After Years of Ambitious Growth, Barclays Seeks to Be Leaner
articles.snippet: The overhaul of the giant British bank signals a shift toward retail and commercial banking and away from Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The overhaul of the giant British bank signals a shift toward retail and commercial banking and away from Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:52 a.m. | LONDON – After decades of building a global investment bank, Barclays is sounding a retreat.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Separatists Defy Kiev and Putin on Referendum
articles.snippet: Leaders of pro-Russian groups in eastern Ukraine said Thursday that they would proceed with the referendum, despite Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s plea to postpone the vote.
articles.abstract: Leaders of pro-Russian groups in eastern Ukraine said Thursday that they would proceed with the referendum, despite Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s plea to postpone the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian militants in eastern Ukraine vowed on Thursday to press ahead with a referendum seeking autonomy, a risky move that seemed to defy their political patron, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, whose motives in urging a delay in the vote came under furious attack by officials in Kiev.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Deflation Threatens Europe. Policy Makers Wait.
articles.snippet: As Europe confronts the prospect of deflation, its top economic officials take a wait-and-see attitude.
articles.abstract: As Europe confronts the prospect of deflation, its top economic officials take a wait-and-see attitude.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe is staring into the face of the kind of deflationary cycle that has paralyzed the Japanese economy for the better part of two decades. Prices are rising far more slowly than its central bank wants, against a backdrop of astronomical unemployment on much of the Continent.
